title: albert0bsd
author: albert0bsd
created_time: July 13, 2023, 03:12:46 PMLast edit: July 18, 2023, 04:08:47 AM by albert0bsd
content: Hi everyone.To keep me some busy i made a small Puzzle for the members of my group in telegram.The Prize is in this Address: 17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9C it have near 100$ USD at current price.The puzzle is contained here:Code:-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----Easy puzzle with 0.0016 BTC @ https://t.me/keyhunters-----BEGIN SIGNATURE-----1HZwkjkeaoZfTSaJxDw6aKkxp45agDiEzNG8jtdFo0RCjSNC8p8qoaE/rhNh9k4uhuF2TqNgBEl2fpP71GjtKC1C3y4yxk54lKutNHH7BoGQQ5SNY2YISNGmU=-----END BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----I did this yesterday and it bring some spark of interest so here are some cluesCode:-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----CluesBehind the result of the equations there are some variables that should Be also a secretBeyond all the discussions, it is worth mentioning that all the possible legacy addresses amount is 2Î›160Every single Byte counts, how many Bytes have this message?This is a signed message with ECDSA. There may be some questions about it.- How do we know the math used in ECDSA is right?- Can someone cheat or change a signed message made with ECDSA?- Is it possible for two different messages to have the same signature?- How can we be sure that the person who signs a message is the real owner of the secret key and not pretending?AlbertoBSD-----BEGIN SIGNATURE-----17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9CH+a3NLPvRfoVgYgZBhvSiGY1001ylS8D5IjRbkrJ/MjlsSTCZ+rC8OIHyCFRwSHwGtIWx+xGIeR4x3nTpl1FUvY=-----END BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----In case that the forum messup the message here is the previous signed message in a text file https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cWlCo7ycY2-jTg575wIukx1p9YJFS2If/view?usp=sharing i already checked it and it is validI sugest to you read ALL the documentation available. Â The ECDSA documentation is here:https://cryptobook.nakov.com/digital-signatures/ecdsa-sign-verify-messagesHere is a tool to verify the signatures easilyhttps://reinproject.org/bitcoin-signature-tool/#verifyAbout this puzzle it don't need any big computer power, but some small calcualtions are needed.There is not a single tool that solve this puzzle with a single line command you need to know what are you doing.If someone found the solution notify me here or in telegram.RegardsSolvedMessages with their signatures:@cryptobank_miki https://t.me/keyhunters/25845Code:-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----I redeemed the puzzle, thanks Alberto!-----BEGIN SIGNATURE-----17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9CIOxI39y3LonkrRkxh87shzE2b93OjKbpiVQ87lR2bUIbtD7t3vuy1vfeJpN92doYWxkWmUG8JQTxBypjb+XZ5z8=-----END BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----@sazilariel https://t.me/keyhunters/26241Code:-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----Thank you Alberto for the fun!-----BEGIN SIGNATURE-----17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9CH3+k7aiNOw/oXNjf9cuvQ+4aRd0QCLWWBgQ4epnYf4upO5DhsL/DB4qlD7ngEY6gqQExNw5MgZBqW2716p8BNVA=-----END BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----

comments.author: albert0bsd
comments.created_time: July 18, 2023, 03:58:52 AMLast edit: July 18, 2023, 04:39:20 AM by albert0bsd
comments.body: How this small puzzle was made.The following were my objectives.- Show the importance of K- Show some math- Show the properties of Endomorphism- To make you think outside the boxSteps to make the puzzle...1.- Search a remarkable address with privatekey in the public Domain2.- Make a signature for that address3.- Decode and extract the values of the Signature values ( R, S and Z )4.- Calculate K with some code in Python or C5.- Use an endomorphims value of K to generate a new Unused Address6.- Send the prize to that new Address and publish the Puzzle.Steps with the Values already used: The remarkable address used was the Address that is generated with the sha256 of an empty string ""CodeCode:echo -n | Â sha256sume3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855 Â - The signature used was publish before. The values of that siganture can be easily extracted with a tool that i madeCode:Final X, Y : c8ed745a344428d2342f29f2aa1a13fae1361f64e2e86e1764ea3600449767e9 0a119788b20caec8a773785c8008eeba3286e35ceb4f7f4df158c280fc338caaFinal R: c8ed745a344428d2342f29f2aa1a13fae1361f64e2e86e1764ea3600449767e9Final S: 3fbd468ed282d42df2e32c64e7894abad3471fb06819043948d63660848d1a65Final Z: ee1842cc42b2cd2dd37415bd7b92fc9380d3324a165f6362a4eedcd93f721e5bCalculated address: 1HZwkjkeaoZfTSaJxDw6aKkxp45agDiEzNCalculated publickey uncompressed: 04a34b99f22c790c4e36b2b3c2c35a36db06226e41c692fc82b8b56ac1c540c5bd5b8dec5235a0fa8722476c7709c02559e3aa73aa03918ba2d492eea75abea235Calculated publickey compressed: 03a34b99f22c790c4e36b2b3c2c35a36db06226e41c692fc82b8b56ac1c540c5bdThe signature match with the address and it is valid-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----Easy puzzle with 0.0016 BTC @ https://t.me/keyhunters-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNATURE-----1HZwkjkeaoZfTSaJxDw6aKkxp45agDiEzNG8jtdFo0RCjSNC8p8qoaE/rhNh9k4uhuF2TqNgBEl2fpP71GjtKC1C3y4yxk54lKutNHH7BoGQQ5SNY2YISNGmU=-----END BITCOIN SIGNATURE----- Calculate K with some code in Python or Cif you askme how to i get the Inverse of the original S value i use a C code, but then i realize that i can use my modmath tool for that:Code:./modmath 1 / 0x3fbd468ed282d42df2e32c64e7894abad3471fb06819043948d63660848d1a65Result: 0xb44ae7316060a9f7af0049effddf65813df443267349cf2a37ca6cb5fb95b4f8Originaly i use a C code, but it can be more easily to use PythonCode:N = 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFEBAAEDCE6AF48A03BBFD25E8CD0364141Sinv = 0xb44ae7316060a9f7af0049effddf65813df443267349cf2a37ca6cb5fb95b4f8Z = 0xee1842cc42b2cd2dd37415bd7b92fc9380d3324a165f6362a4eedcd93f721e5bR = 0xc8ed745a344428d2342f29f2aa1a13fae1361f64e2e86e1764ea3600449767e9dA = 0xe3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855K = Sinv *(Z + R*dA) % Nhex(K)The output:Code:>>> hex(K)'0x414bbbb61505e0304ec9399dff8967ce5619a10e5829d3b06ea44295c4166746'At this point we are in half way to solve the puzzle.The math part of th puzzle is to use Algebra to reorder the Signature proof ecuation:OriginallyS = K^-1 * (Z + R *dA ) % NIt was just reorder:K = S^-1 * (Z + R *dA ) % NUsually if we already have the private key (dA) then the nonce (K) value is useless but as a practice exercise get the K value of each one of your Transactions is very good learning exercise. To use endomorphims to calcualte some Alternate Address from the K nonce we can use also modmathCode:./modmath 0x414bbbb61505e0304ec9399dff8967ce5619a10e5829d3b06ea44295c4166746 x 0xac9c52b33fa3cf1f5ad9e3fd77ed9ba4a880b9fc8ec739c2e0cfc810b51283ceResult: 0x7191e2fd37f1b8657e471afde6d9bb52a287f33da902423abac278e9f5dcd23dThen we only need to use a tool like calculatefromkey or some page like https://www.bitaddress.org/ to get the compressed address from that KEYNow than you already know how the puzzle was made then you know how to solve it, but i wan to show you three approach to solve it. Approach with the Y value.If you get the RSZ values from the Second signature (Clues signature)Command:Code:./verifymsg -v -a 17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9C -s "H+a3NLPvRfoVgYgZBhvSiGY1001ylS8D5IjRbkrJ/MjlsSTCZ+rC8OIHyCFRwSHwGtIWx+xGIeR4x3nTpl1FUvY=" -m "$(cat ~/text.txt)"Final X, Y : e6b734b3ef45fa15818819061bd2886635d34d72952f03e488d16e4ac9fcc8e5 28f7b4f4501644cb0ea9dd09dfb5494b7537aa784518bd2af24c8c8b0b7476f2Final R: e6b734b3ef45fa15818819061bd2886635d34d72952f03e488d16e4ac9fcc8e5Final S: b124c267eac2f0e207c82151c121f01ad216c7ec4621e478c779d3a65d4552f6Final Z: 80b5e209faa552bab934589fbc0d4727eb0431a32218a6f606d9a0486b1a42ecCalculated address: 17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9CCalculated publickey compressed: 02ec24fc672cf31509d75fb84d2ae5b2faa862aa54344a2db451e42d620e5eac2aCalculated publickey uncompressed: 04ec24fc672cf31509d75fb84d2ae5b2faa862aa54344a2db451e42d620e5eac2a0a119788b20caec8a773785c8008eeba3286e35ceb4f7f4df158c280fc338caaThe signature match with the address and it is valid-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNED MESSAGE-----CluesBehind the result of the equations there are some variables that should Be also a secretBeyond all the discussions, it is worth mentioning that all the possible legacy addresses amount is 2Î›160Every single Byte counts, how many Bytes have this message?This is a signed message with ECDSA. There may be some questions about it.- How do we know the math used in ECDSA is right?- Can someone cheat or change a signed message made with ECDSA?- Is it possible for two different messages to have the same signature?- How can we be sure that the person who signs a message is the real owner of the secret key and not pretending?AlbertoBSD-----BEGIN BITCOIN SIGNATURE-----17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9CH+a3NLPvRfoVgYgZBhvSiGY1001ylS8D5IjRbkrJ/MjlsSTCZ+rC8OIHyCFRwSHwGtIWx+xGIeR4x3nTpl1FUvY=-----END BITCOIN SIGNATURE-----If you carefully check all the values here you can notice that Y value from the Nonce in the first message is the same tha the Y value of the publickey of the prize adressYou don't belive me? check:First signaute fragmentCode:Final X, Y : c8ed745a344428d2342f29f2aa1a13fae1361f64e2e86e1764ea3600449767e9 0a119788b20caec8a773785c8008eeba3286e35ceb4f7f4df158c280fc338caaSecond signature fragmentCode:Calculated publickey uncompressed: 04ec24fc672cf31509d75fb84d2ae5b2faa862aa54344a2db451e42d620e5eac2a0a119788b20caec8a773785c8008eeba3286e35ceb4f7f4df158c280fc338caaLook carefully, if you don't know nothing about endomorphism you may ask to chatGPT or some other AI, or even ask in a forum, the may point you in the right way to solve it.At this point if you missed the Y value in those publickeys you may need some glasses (No offence but the values were there visible for everyone) Approach with the keyhuntOnce than you already calculate the K value you can use keyhunt to search it:Code:./keyhunt -m address -f target.txt -e -r 414bbbb61505e0304ec9399dff8967ce5619a10e5829d3b06ea44295c4166746[+] Version 0.2.230507 Satoshi Quest (legacy), developed by AlbertoBSD[+] Mode address[+] Endomorphism enabled[+] Setting search for btc adddress[+] N = 0x100000000[+] Range[+] -- from : 0x414bbbb61505e0304ec9399dff8967ce5619a10e5829d3b06ea44295c4166746[+] -- to Â  : 0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffebaaedce6af48a03bbfd25e8cd0364141[+] Allocating memory for 1 elements: 0.00 MB[+] Bloom filter for 1 elements.[+] Loading data to the bloomfilter total: 0.03 MB[+] Sorting data ... done! 1 values were loaded and sortedBase key: 414bbbb61505e0304ec9399dff8967ce5619a10e5829d3b06ea44295c4166746Hit! Private Key: 7191e2fd37f1b8657e471afde6d9bb52a287f33da902423abac278e9f5dcd23dpubkey: 02ec24fc672cf31509d75fb84d2ae5b2faa862aa54344a2db451e42d620e5eac2aAddress 17hxfkNjHb2d68PFcUKHeLLwbcwnXBTa9Crmd160 498fdccf23d5e95fc5b3b93a4b4c6dcd334f512d^C Approach with the clues.Code:Behind the result of the equations there are some variables that should Be also a secretThis in my indirect way to tell you that you need to search for all the secrets in the equations. What Equations?Code:This is a signed message with ECDSA.Well you need to search what kind of equatios are involved in the ECDSA process, i paste the proper link in the first postCode:Every single Byte counts, how many Bytes have this message?With message i mean all the text that is begin signed in that second signature.How many bytes it have, did you count it?The message is 652 bytes, but if you select the characters in a text editor it only select 646 characters that including the Return lines,Where comes this difference?Use hexedit :Code:00000000 Â  43 6C 75 65 Â 73 0A CE 92 Â 65 68 69 6E 3F 0A Â 2D 20 43 61 Â 6E 20 73 6F Â 6D 65 6F 6E Â 65 20 63 68 Â  right?.- Can someone ch00000198 Â  65 61 74 20 Â 6F 72 20 63 Â 68 61 6E 67 Â 65 20 61 20 Â 73 69 67 6E Â 65 64 20 6D Â eat or change a Â  Â  Â  Â  oBSDIf you see the Values of the characters and check for printable Characters maybe you will notice that some of them are missing in the printable part:Those characters are: B and Î› (Beta and Lambda). You may not be an "expert" in soma field of study but you have google or all those new AI.Check this questions on ChatGPT:Code:Q: Is there something oddly in the Text of the clues ?A: Yes, there is something odd in the text of the clues. The oddity lies in the usage of the letter "B" (capital beta) instead of the letter "B" (capital bee) in several instances. It appears that the letter "B" has been mistakenly used instead of "B" throughout the text.For example, the clues should read:"Behind the result of the equations there are some variables that should be also a secret.""Beyond all the discussions, it is worth mentioning that all the possible legacy addresses amount is 2^160.""Every single Byte counts, how many Bytes have this message?"The presence of the letter "B" instead of "B" seems to be a typographical error or an unintended character substitution. It is important to note this discrepancy and ensure that the correct letter "B" is used when interpreting the text and attempting to solve the puzzle.Q: what is B and Î› and how they are related to eliptic curvesA: In the context of elliptic curves, B (Beta) and Î› (Lambda) are parameters that are often used to describe the equations of elliptic curves in a specific form known as Weierstrass form.The Weierstrass form of an elliptic curve is given by the equation:y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B,where A and B are constants that depend on the specific curve. The values of A and B determine the shape and properties of the curve.In this equation, B represents the constant term, which affects the vertical shift of the curve. It determines the y-coordinate of the point at infinity (the point that serves as the identity element in elliptic curve group operations).Î›, on the other hand, is a parameter used in the definition of the group law on an elliptic curve. The group law specifies how to add two points on the curve to obtain a third point. Î› is related to the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a specific point. It is used to compute the x-coordinate of the sum of two points.To summarize, B determines the vertical shift of the curve, while Î› is involved in the group law calculations on the curve. These parameters are important in describing and working with elliptic curves in the Weierstrass form.As you see you can use the AI as entry point of informationWhat about the other clues?Code:- How do we know the math used in ECDSA is right?- Can someone cheat or change a signed message made with ECDSA?- Is it possible for two different messages to have the same signature?- How can we be sure that the person who signs a message is the real owner of the secret key and not pretending?Those are just valid question that you may ask to your self and search or think in what are some conditions mathematically needed to do something or prevent something.That is all...Regards

comments.author: digaran
comments.body: So what was the answer to this puzzle? I mean what did we learn from it exactly?

comments.author: albert0bsd
comments.body: Quote from: digaran on July 18, 2023, 10:33:25 AMSo what was the answer to this puzzle? I mean what did we learn from it exactly?- Calculate the K value when you have the privatekey- understand that K nonce is like another privatekey- Endomorphims- Use algebra to reorder the equations.- To use every single hint, or oddly data.- To search on any search engine available.Quote from: MagicByt3 on July 18, 2023, 09:22:29 AMGreat puzzle Alberto.I hope to see more of them in future. Â Thank you, I am going to make some of them, but I am not be able to sponsor more prizes like that, but I may add another kind of reward.
